title: Method statement for safeguarding trees within a planning application, in a Conservation Area

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
My question is with regard to planning application process.
At what juncture would a tree report and method statement for safeguarding measures* to be taken whilst working around large, mature trees - be formally requested from a contractor applying to carry out works within a Conservation Area?
Yours faithfully,
Dr Deepa Shetty MRCVS
*Protective measures might include British Standard 5837 recommendations, for example. Avoiding compaction and excavation within the root protection area (RPA), unless directly under arboricultural supervision e.g. if large roots are discovered and requiring specialist instruction on how to proceed without impacting the health of the tree.

Dear Deepa Shetty,
Thank you for your request for information relating to planning
application procedure which we received on 22/07/2024.
As your request is a request for information relating to the environment,
this has been logged as a request under the Environmental Information
Regulations 2004 (EIR) and will be dealt with under the Regulations. The
reference number for your request can be found above.
The Environmental Information Regulations 2004 state that we must respond
to you within 20 working days, by 23/08/2024. Please do not hesitate to
contact us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Deepa Shetty,
Thank you for your request for information relating to planning
application procedure which we received on 22/07/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
At what juncture would a tree report and method statement for safeguarding
measures* to be taken whilst working around large, mature trees - be
formally requested from a contractor applying to carry out works within a
Conservation Area?
This is considered to be more of a request for general advice as to how
the service operates rather than a specific information request.
Please note that this is a very broad hypothetical question that would
depend upon the specifics of a particular case (i.e. each case on its
merits which is an imbedded principle when it comes to the assessment of
planning applications).
Within the planning process it is rare that applications are received
directly from contractors. Usually, applications are made by private
individuals or developers. The applicant is referred to as the applicant,
but often applications are submitted by representatives that have been
appointed by an applicant who are known as agents in the process.
Your question does not distinguish between whether the form of works
proposed would be forms of operational development requiring planning
permission, or whether the works referred to are specific tree works to
trees within a Conservation Area which do not involve any forms of
operational development as well.
We would advise that there is an application type for both, although with
the former tree works can be assessed as part of the application for
planning permission without the need for an additional application only
for the tree works which would be superfluous.
If a large mature tree within a Conservation Area was in close proximity
to a form of operational development that requires planning permission the
variables would depend upon the specific development proposal in question,
the proximity to the tree and its anticipated root protection area.
For something like a new building, it is likely that a tree survey and
impact assessment conforming to British Standard 5837: 2012 would be
requested either at validation or assessment stages prior to the decision
being made. If a proposal is judged acceptable leading to the granting of
planning permission, it is then commonplace that conditions are imposed
requiring tree protection measures to be installed prior to works
commencing and for the duration of the construction period.
However, for smaller scale works there would be a number of variables and
the information requirements and conditions would depend on the
circumstances involved with proportionality being a factor. As a service
planning would consult with the Council’s specialist Landscaping Officers
on relevant proposals in order to receive guidance on whether trees would
be likely to be impacted by the works proposed, the type of information
that should be sought from applicants and on the need for specific
conditions as part of the assessment process prior to the decision being
made.
In addition, there are various forms of operational development that can
be undertaken without any form of planning permission by virtue of the
national permitted development rights that are set out within The Town and
Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as
amended). For works which are permitted development the Council has no
power to request information on safeguarding measures for existing trees
in Conservation Areas. However persons wishing to carry out such permitted
development works are still bound by section 211 of the Town and Country
Planning Act 1990:- [1]Town and Country Planning Act 1990
(legislation.gov.uk)
If a planning application was found to have been misleading with respect
to the works to be carried out within a Conservation Area, what is the
procedure in terms of rectification. At what juncture would a request be
made for works to be halted and the application resubmitted?
*Protective measures might include British Standard 5837 recommendations,
for example. Avoiding compaction and excavation within the root protection
area (RPA), unless directly under arboricultural supervision e.g. if large
roots are discovered and requiring specialist instruction on how to
proceed without impacting the health of the tree.
Please note that this is a very broad hypothetical question that would
depend upon the specifics of a particular case.
Initially the process would rely upon a complaint being registered with
the Planning Enforcement service:-[2]Reporting a planning enforcement
issue | Sheffield City Council
Planning Enforcement would then investigate the complaint to understand
whether there is a breach of the planning permission.
If so, there is a range of ways of tackling alleged breaches of planning
control, and local planning authorities should act in a proportionate way.
Local planning authorities have discretion to take enforcement action,
when they regard it as expedient to do so having regard to the development
plan and any other material considerations. The national guidance on the
processes we are required to follow is available publicly using the
following weblink:- [3]Enforcement and post-permission matters - GOV.UK
(www.gov.uk)
If the enforcement investigation finds that works are being carried out in
accordance with a particular planning permission the options available to
Local Planning Authority’s are fairly limited in that we do not have the
power to withdraw a permission unilaterally without the payment of
compensation. For that reason, the powers under S97 of the Town and
Country Planning Act are very rarely used by LPA’s throughout the Country.
[4]
https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/199...
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [5]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[6]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
